channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Wanted: Junior Perl Developer Ready to Move Up from the Bunny Hill
item.description: Our client is looking for a junior developer with at least two years of professional experience. They want someone who has conquered a mountain of SQL queries; a slope-star with working knowledge of enough HTML, CSS, and JavaScript to build robust user interfaces that wonâ€™t wipe out in a cloud of powder.

item.title: Mojolicious, GraphQL, and Perl Consultant (Poland and Central Europe)
item.description: Want to program in Perl, but not ready to give up on pierogi? Enchanted by the dynamism of Central Europe, and want to put your Modern Perl skills to good use? Our client is looking for a Perl consultant in their Polish or Hungarian offices.

item.title: Seeking Abominable Snowman (or Snowwoman) for Junior Perl Developer Role!
item.description: The role is located in Villars-sur-Ollon, Vaud, Switzerland. Sport enthusiasts may know this as one of the best outdoor playgrounds in the world. Spend winters skiing or snowboarding, and in the summer, hike or bike over those same slopes to cheese farms and wine caves.

item.title: Crank out Mojolicious and DBIx::Class in Scandinavia
item.description: Our client is looking for a strong Modern Perl consultant developer in their Stockholm or Scandinavian offices. Theyâ€™re really keen on someone who will hit the ground running â€“ youâ€™ll be expected to already be accomplished with Modern Perl tooling, and theyâ€™ll want you to be composing resultsets with DBIx::Class on day one.

item.title: DevOps Daredevil Ready for Double Black Diamond Adventure
item.description: Youâ€™ve been swishing down the slopes for a little while now. Youâ€™ve got a handle on the strengths and weaknesses of AWS RDS, and MySQL replication is as simple as a trip down the bunny hill. But are you ready to move up to the double black diamond?

item.title: NICEPERL's lists

Great modules released last week;
MetaCPAN weekly report;
StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: Larry has approved renaming Perl 6 to raku
item.description: There are a lot of good points in this post, but Ovid also writes: "Though support for a rename was overwhelming, there was a loud minority who objected", but he shows no evidence of this. For all I know there were 8 billion people who silently supported the name change and 20 'loudmouthes' who were actually involved in the project who opposed it. I don't know. It just seems like bending the truth. It is definitely trumping on the people who 'lost' the argument. Then giving them a bone by writing: "But through it all, one thing remained clear: everyone meant well.". And all this is coming from a well-respected member of the Perl community.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge W029 - Brace Expansion
item.description: Yet Ebreo blog is very well inline documented blog.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge W029 - Calling C
item.description: Yet Ebreo showed how Fibonacci series is generated using C and called from Perl script.

item.description: Roger introduced FFI::Raw to show how it can be used to call C funciton. Must Read.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 29: Brace Expansion and Calling C Code
item.description: Laurent blog is something you can't afford to miss. You must checkout.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 029: Brace expansion and calling a C function
item.description: E. Choroba always surprised me with his cjoice CPAN module. This time he used Syntax::Contruct. Checkout what he is doing with it.

item.title: Code "Reuse" and Perl Weekly Challenge #29
item.description: I really enjoyed how solved the calling C function from perl script task. So simple and easy to follow.

item.title: Bracen C with Perl 6
item.description: As always Perl6 doesn't need lots of coding. Checkout the Perl6 magic.

item.title: Grant Extension Request: Maintaining the Perl 5 Core (Tony Cook)
Paws for Fun and Profit. Part the First.
item.description: He is back! After a very long break John has restarted his almost daily blog posts. This is the first episode. You can find the rest in the list of posts in October. See below!

item.title: London Perl Workshop is this weekend!
item.description: October 19, 2019. David Game College, 31 Jewry St, London EC3N 2ET

item.title: #429 - Name and identity
item.description:
Hi there!

It feels strange writing this from the stage of the Perl weekly newsletter, but I am happy with the renaming of Perl 6 to something unrelated to Perl. It will hopefully give a better chance for it to shine.

Some of the Perl programmers will still blame Perl 6 (or Raku) for the fact that less people use Perl today, but hopefully the name change will reduce this type of noise. This will give a better opportunity to the Perl 6 / Raku developers to enjoy the fruits of their labor.

For a long time I was hoping for the simple solution explained by Andrew Shitov, but I am afraid some people in the Perl community would not allow that. At least not socially.

So as much as it hurts, I think separating from Perl is in the best interest of Perl 6 / Raku.

Enjoy your week!

ps. I might need to add a subtitle to the newsletter: "covering Perl, Raku, and everything related."
